Linear Fixed Effect Model

Source: vignettes/Linear-FE.Rmd
Linear-FE.Rmd

Estimation

In general R methods such as lm and glm, fitting fixed-effects models requires converting the provider factor into dummy variables. Each provider is represented by one dummy column in the design matrix ğƒ\mathbf{D}, set to 1 for observations belonging to that provider and 0 otherwise. Combined with the covariate matrix ğ™\mathbf{Z}, the full design matrix is ğ—=[ğ™,ğƒ]\mathbf{X} = [\mathbf{Z}, \mathbf{D}], where ğ™\mathbf{Z} is the covariate matrix and ğƒ\mathbf{D} is the mm-column dummy matrix indicating provider membership.

When the number of providers mm is large, creating and inverting this many dummy variables becomes computationally expensive in terms of both memory and processing time. To avoid the high dimensionality of dummy variables, pprof uses a profile likelihood approach. The ordinary least squares objective is

S(Î³,Î²)=âˆ‘i=1mâˆ‘j=1ni(Yijâˆ’Î³iâˆ’ğ™ijâŠ¤ğ›ƒ)2. S(\gamma, \beta) = \sum_{i=1}^{m} \sum_{j=1}^{n_i} \bigl(Y_{ij} - \gamma_i - \mathbf{Z}_{ij}^\top \boldsymbol\beta\bigr)^2.

Fixing ğ›ƒ\boldsymbol\beta, set âˆ‚Sâˆ‚Î³i=0\frac{\partial S}{\partial \gamma_i} = 0 to obtain

Î³Ì‚FE,i=Yâ€¾iâˆ’ğ™â€¾iâŠ¤ğ›ƒ,i=1,â€¦,m, \hat\gamma_{FE,i} = \bar{Y}_i - \bar{\mathbf{Z}}_i^\top \boldsymbol\beta, \quad i = 1, \ldots, m,

where

Yâ€¾i=niâˆ’1âˆ‘j=1niYij,ğ™â€¾i=niâˆ’1âˆ‘j=1niğ™ij. \bar{Y}_i = n_i^{-1}\sum_{j=1}^{n_i} Y_{ij}, \quad \bar{\mathbf{Z}}_i = n_i^{-1}\sum_{j=1}^{n_i} \mathbf{Z}_{ij}.

Substituting back yields the profile objective for ğ›ƒ\boldsymbol\beta, equivalent to centering each providerâ€™s data:

YÌƒij=ğ™ÌƒijâŠ¤ğ›ƒ+ÏµÌƒij, \tilde{Y}_{ij} = \tilde{\mathbf{Z}}_{ij}^\top \boldsymbol\beta + \tilde{\epsilon}_{ij},

with YÌƒij=Yijâˆ’Yâ€¾i,ğ™Ìƒij=ğ™ijâˆ’ğ™â€¾i,ÏµÌƒij=Ïµijâˆ’Ïµâ€¾i\tilde{Y}_{ij} = Y_{ij} - \bar{Y}_i, \tilde{\mathbf{Z}}_{ij} = \mathbf{Z}_{ij} - \bar{\mathbf{Z}}_i, \tilde{\epsilon}_{ij} = \epsilon_{ij} - \bar{\epsilon}_i.

Estimation of Regression Coefficients

The closed-form estimator for ğ›ƒ\boldsymbol\beta is

ğ›ƒÌ‚FE=(âˆ‘i=1mâˆ‘j=1niğ™Ìƒijğ™ÌƒijâŠ¤)âˆ’1(âˆ‘i=1mâˆ‘j=1niğ™ÌƒijYÌƒij)=(âˆ‘i=1mğ™iâŠ¤ğiğ™i)âˆ’1(âˆ‘i=1mğ™iâŠ¤ğiğ˜i), \widehat{\boldsymbol\beta}_{FE} = \Bigl(\sum_{i=1}^m \sum_{j=1}^{n_i} \tilde{\mathbf{Z}}_{ij} \tilde{\mathbf{Z}}_{ij}^\top\Bigr)^{-1} \Bigl(\sum_{i=1}^m \sum_{j=1}^{n_i} \tilde{\mathbf{Z}}_{ij} \tilde{Y}_{ij}\Bigr) = \Bigl(\sum_{i=1}^m \mathbf{Z}_i^\top \mathbf{Q}_i \mathbf{Z}_i\Bigr)^{-1} \Bigl(\sum_{i=1}^m \mathbf{Z}_i^\top \mathbf{Q}_i \mathbf{Y}_i\Bigr),

where ği=ğˆniâˆ’ğŸniğŸniâŠ¤/ni\mathbf{Q}_i = \mathbf{I}_{n_i} - \mathbf{1}_{n_i}\mathbf{1}_{n_i}^\top / n_i.

Variance and Inference

The residual variance is estimated by

ÏƒÌ‚Ïµ2=1nâˆ’mâˆ’pâˆ‘i=1mâˆ‘j=1ni(Yijâˆ’Î³Ì‚FE,iâˆ’ğ™ijâŠ¤ğ›ƒÌ‚FE)2. \hat\sigma_{\epsilon}^2 = \frac{1}{n - m - p} \sum_{i=1}^m \sum_{j=1}^{n_i} \bigl(Y_{ij} - \hat\gamma_{FE,i} - \mathbf{Z}_{ij}^\top \widehat{\boldsymbol\beta}_{FE}\bigr)^2.

Under this model, ğ›ƒÌ‚FE\widehat{\boldsymbol\beta}_{FE} and Î³Ì‚FE,i\hat\gamma_{FE,i} are unbiased, with

Var(ğ›ƒÌ‚FE)=ÏƒÏµ2(âˆ‘i=1mğ™iâŠ¤ğiğ™i)âˆ’1,Var(Î³Ì‚FE,i)=ÏƒÏµ2ni. \mathrm{Var}(\widehat{\boldsymbol\beta}_{FE}) = \sigma_{\epsilon}^2 \Bigl(\sum_{i=1}^m \mathbf{Z}_i^\top \mathbf{Q}_i \mathbf{Z}_i\Bigr)^{-1}, \quad \mathrm{Var}(\hat\gamma_{FE,i}) = \frac{\sigma_{\epsilon}^2}{n_i}.
